Fiction

BEFORE I SAY GOOD-BYE, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) A woman with ESP searches for the truth behind the death of her husband, who was killed when his boat exploded in New York Harbor.
EASY PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $25.95.) The homicide detective Lucas Davenport investigates the strangulation of a famous model.
THE WEDDING, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $26.95.) Allegra Steinberg, an entertainment lawyer, makes plans to marry a New York writer in her parents' Bel Air home.
THE BLUEST EYE, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $15.) The story of an 11-year-old black girl -- pregnant by her father -- who prays for her eyes to turn blue.
THE BRETHREN, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) Three former judges, doing time at a federal prison in Florida, concoct a mail scam that goes awry.
HARRY POTTER AND THE PRISONER OF AZKABAN, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $19.95.) A British boy's life at a school for witchcraft is threatened.
HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $17.95.) A British boy finds trouble when he returns to a witchcraft school.
STANDOFF, by Sandra Brown. (Warner, $19.95.) A television reporter finds herself protecting the runaway teenage daughter of a multimillionaire from Texas.
STAR WARS: Rogue Planet, by Greg Bear. (Lucas/ Del Rey/Ballantine, $26.) Obi-Wan Kenobi and Anakin Skywalker are swept up in a world of deadly intrigue.
BACK ROADS, by Tawni O'Dell. (Viking, $24.95.) The ordeals of a 19-year-old man in western Pennsylvania who must care for his three younger sisters.
THE EMPTY CHAIR, by Jeffery Deaver. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) Forensic specialists pursue a disturbed teenage boy who abducted two young women.
BEOWULF, translated by Seamus Heaney. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) A new rendering of the Anglo-Saxon epic by a Nobel Prize-winning Irish poet.
HE SHALL THUNDER IN THE SKY, by Elizabeth Peters. (Morrow, $25.) In Cairo in 1914, the archaeologist-sleuth Amelia Peabody must confront her archenemy.
*HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $16.95.) A British boy finds his fortune attending a school for witchcraft.
THE HEIR, by Johanna Lindsey. (Morrow, $24.) A young woman taking part in the coming-out season in London experiences a forbidden romance.

'TIS, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $26.) An Irish immigrant gets used to life in America: a memoir.
THE GREATEST GENERATION, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The lives of men and women who came of age during the Depression and World War II.
THE MILLIONAIRE MIND, by Thomas J. Stanley. (Andrews McMeel, $26.95.) An analysis of the wealthy elite.
*THE ROCK SAYS . . ., by the Rock with Joe Layden. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $26.) A memoir by a professional wrestler.
*THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead, $22.95.) What Buddhism and common sense tell us about everyday problems.

IN THE HEART OF THE SEA, by Nathaniel Philbrick. (Viking, $24.95.) The story of the whaleship Essex, whose disastrous fate in the early 19th century would later serve as inspiration for Herman Melville.
CYBILL DISOBEDIENCE, by Cybill Shepherd with Aimee Lee Ball. (HarperCollins, $26.) A memoir by the film and television actress.
*FAIR BALL, by Bob Costas. (Broadway, $21.95.) The sportscaster's critique of major league baseball.
*THE CASE AGAINST HILLARY CLINTON, by Peggy Noonan. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $24.) A former Reagan speechwriter calls the first lady to account. (+)
THE MEASURE OF A MAN, by Sidney Poitier. (HarperSanFrancisco, $26.) The movie actor's spiritual autobiography.
A HEARTBREAKING WORK OF STAGGERING GENIUS, by Dave Eggers. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) A young man's account of raising his 8-year-old brother.
*THE TIPPING POINT, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) A journalist's study of social epidemics, otherwise known as fads.
*THE CAMINO, by Shirley MacLaine. (Pocket, $24.95.) A ''journey of the spirit'' takes the actress from present-day Spain through past lives to the origin of the universe.

And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

THE BINDING CHAIR: Or, A Visit From the Foot Emancipation Society, by Kathryn Harrison. (Random House, $24.95.) A resonant, elaborately constructed novel that renders the lives of two women, an aunt deformed physically and morally by tradition and her overtly rebellious niece.

BOBOS IN PARADISE: The New Upper Class and How They Got There, by David Brooks. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) Affection, ridicule and plain ambivalence propel this work of ''comic sociology'' as it examines the rise of the ''bourgeois bohemian,'' the social and economic type that now controls and consumes everything.

THE BOY WITH THE THORN IN HIS SIDE: A Memoir, by Keith Fleming. (Morrow, $24.) The tale of a troubled straight teenager sent to live with his uncle, Edmund White, one of the best-known, best-liked gay men on earth, who turned out to be exactly the ideal trustworthy parent.

THE FEAST OF LOVE, by Charles Baxter. (Pantheon, $24.) A luminous he-said-she-said of a novel, in which He, a handsome toadlike man, and She, Ex-Wife No. 1, unspool contrary narratives of their life together.

FROM DAWN TO DECADENCE: 500 Years of western cultural life, 1500 to the present, by Jacques Barzun. (HarperCollins, $36.) Who else would have the nerve to write a book by this name, or the range and clarity to succeed? The sole unpleasant prospect is the vile 20th century.

THE HUMAN STAIN, by Philip Roth. (Houghton Mifflin, $26.) The novel's doomed protagonist is a modern converso: a black man passing as a Jew so he'll be taken for white; our old friend Nathan Zuckerman tells his story.

JOHN RUSKIN: The Later Years, by Tim Hilton. (Yale University, $35.) Opening when its subject is 40 and a rising authority on aesthetics, Volume II of this vast biography charts Ruskin's unraveling from passionate cataloger (rocks, plants, buildings, paintings, clouds) to tragic obsessive (irrigation, drainage, running water, little girls).

KARL MARX: A Life, by Francis Wheen. (Norton, $27.95.) An engaging reinterpretation of the prophet's life that defends his ideas (not very persuasively) but emphasizes his Victorian male egocentricity and bourgeois pretensions.

THE MANY ASPECTS OF MOBILE HOME LIVING, by Martin Clark. (Knopf, $24.) This first novel by a Southern judge features . . . a Southern judge, who logs overtime as cuckold, bribe taker, treasure hunter and tester of abused substances but by the end has become well worth knowing.
NEWJACK: Guarding Sing Sing, by Ted Conover. (Random House, $24.95.) A journalist's account of his year as a correction officer, where his moral well-being was as much at risk as his bodily safety.
